questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is an example of an application using Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)?
question_texts: Which of the following is an example of an application using Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)?

options.option_text: A system where users are granted access based on their job roles within anorganization.
A cloud service that grants or restricts access to files based on attributes suchas user department, job title, or current location.
A file-sharing system where the file owner decides who can access theirdocuments.
A system that enforces access based on security classifications and clearancelevels.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements about the Constraint Validation API is/are true?
question_texts: Which of the following statements about the Constraint Validation API is/are true?

options.option_text: The Constraint Validation API ensures that form input meets client-sidevalidation rules before submission.
The Constraint Validation API is sufficient to prevent server-side attacks likeSQL injection.
It is possible to bypass the Constraint Validation API by directly sendingrequests to the server.
The Constraint Validation API automatically validates all data on the serverside.

The primary key allows duplicate values
The primary key can be referenced by foreign keys in other tables.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Diploma Level: Modern Application Development I"** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts** ### **1. Web Development (Flask, Jinja2, HTML/CSS/JS)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Flask Framework**: - Routing (`@app.route`), request handling (`request.args`, `request.form`). - Template rendering (`render_template`, Jinja2 syntax: `{{ }}`, `{% %}`). - Context managers (`test_request_context`). - Error handling (`abort`, `@app.errorhandler`). - Logging (`app.logger`, `logging.basicConfig`). - RESTful APIs (`flask_restful`, `Resource`, `reqparse`). - **Jinja2 Templating**: - Variable substitution (`{{ var }}`). - Control structures (`{% if %}`, `{% for %}`). - Filters (`|default`, `|int`). - Template inheritance (`{% extends %}`, `{% block %}`). - **HTML/CSS/JS**: - DOM manipulation (`document.getElementById`, `style.fontWeight`). - Event handling (`onclick`). - CSS specificity (inline vs. class vs. ID selectors). - List styling (`
    `, `
      `, `display: inline-block`). #### **Key Equations/Code Snippets:** - **Flask Route**: ```python @app.route('/path/') def func(variable): return render_template('file.html', data=data) ``` - **Jinja2 Template**: ```html

      {{ title }}

      {% for item in items %}
    • {{ item }}
      • {% endfor %} ``` - **DOM Manipulation (JS)**: ```javascript document.getElementById("id").style.property = "value"; ``` --- ### **2. Databases (SQLite, SQLAlchemy, ORM)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **SQLAlchemy ORM**: - Model definitions (`db.Model`, `db.Column`, `db.ForeignKey`). - Relationships (One-to-Many, Many-to-Many, One-to-One). - Querying (`Model.query.filter_by()`). - **SQLite**: - Foreign keys (`db.ForeignKey`). - Primary keys (`primary_key=True`). #### **Key Code Snippets:** - **SQLAlchemy Model**: ```python class Library(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) books = db.relationship('Book', backref='library') ``` - **Querying**: ```python books = Book.query.filter_by(library_id=1).all() ``` --- ### **3. Testing (Pytest, Assertions)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Pytest**: - Fixtures (`@pytest.fixture`). - Assertions (`assert condition`). - Test functions (`test_*` naming convention). - Command-line execution (`pytest file.py`). #### **Key Code Snippets:** - **Test Function**: ```python def test_func(): assert function(input) == expected_output ``` - **Fixture**: ```python @pytest.fixture def data(): return {"key": "value"} ``` --- ### **4. Data Structures & Algorithms** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Time Complexity**: - Bandwidth decay (exponential: `bandwidth = initial * (1/2)^hours`). - Data storage (bits/bytes calculations). #### **Key Equations:** - **Bandwidth Decay**: \[ \text{Data} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} \text{bandwidth} \times \text{time} \] Example: Bandwidth halves every hour → Total data = \(4 + 2 + 1 = 7\) Mbps over 3 hours. - **Bit/Byte Conversion**: \[ \text{Bytes} = \frac{\text{Bits}}{8}, \quad \text{Megabytes} = \frac{\text{Kilobytes}}{1000} \] --- ### **5. Access Control & Security** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)**: - Access granted based on attributes (e.g., department, role). - **Constraint Validation API**: - Client-side validation (not sufficient for security). - **Primary/Foreign Keys**: - Primary key: Unique, non-null. - Foreign key: References primary key in another table. --- ### **6. APIs & HTTP Methods** #### **Key Concepts:** - **RESTful APIs**: - HTTP methods (`GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`). - Status codes (`200 OK`, `201 Created`, `400 Bad Request`, `404 Not Found`). - `curl` commands for testing endpoints. #### **Key Code Snippets:** - **Flask RESTful**: ```python class Resource(Resource): def get(self, id): return {"data": id} ``` - **cURL Request**: ```bash curl -X PUT http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/update -d '{"key":"value"}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" ``` --- ### **7. Frontend Technologies** #### **Key Concepts:** - **HTML Lists**: - Ordered (`
        `), unordered (`
          `). - **CSS**: - Selectors (`#id`, `.class`). - Box model (`display`, `border`). - **JavaScript**: - DOM events (`onclick`). - Style manipulation (`element.style.property`). --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graph** ```mermaid graph TD %% Web Development A[Web Development] --> B[Flask] A --> C[Jinja2] A --> D[HTML/CSS/JS] B --> B1[Routing] B --> B2[Templating] B --> B3[RESTful APIs] C --> C1[Variables] C --> C2[Loops/Conditionals] D --> D1[DOM Manipulation] D --> D2[Event Handling] %% Databases E[Databases] --> F[SQLAlchemy] E --> G[SQLite] F --> F1[ORM Models] F --> F2[Relationships] G --> G1[Foreign Keys] %% Testing H[Testing] --> I[Pytest] I --> I1[Fixtures] I --> I2[Assertions] %% Data Structures J[Data Structures] --> K[Bandwidth Decay] K --> K1[Exponential Decay] J --> L[Bit/Byte Calculations] %% Security M[Security] --> N[ABAC] M --> O[Constraint Validation API] M --> P[Primary/Foreign Keys] %% APIs Q[APIs] --> R[HTTP Methods] Q --> S[Status Codes] Q --> T[cURL] %% Frontend U[Frontend] --> V[HTML Lists] U --> W[CSS] U --> X[JavaScript] ``` ```mermaid graph TD %% Relationships Between Topics Flask -->|Uses| Jinja2 Flask -->|Handles| HTTP_Methods Jinja2 -->|Renders| HTML SQLAlchemy -->|Maps_to| SQLite Pytest -->|Tests| Flask Pytest -->|Validates| JavaScript Bandwidth_Decay -->|Calculates| Data_Usage ABAC -->|Secures| APIs Primary_Keys -->|Enforces| Data_Integrity ``` --- ## **Key Equations (Math-Related)** 1. **Bandwidth Decay**: \[ \text{Total Data} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} \text{bandwidth}_i \times \text{time}_i \] Example: \(4 \text{ Mbps} \times 1 \text{ hr} + 2 \text{ Mbps} \times 1 \text{ hr} + 1 \text{ Mbps} \times 1 \text{ hr} = 7 \text{ Mbps}\). 2. **Bit to Byte Conversion**: \[ \text{Bytes} = \frac{\text{Bits}}{8}, \quad \text{KB} = \frac{\text{Bytes}}{1000} \] Example: \(8000 \text{ bits} = 1000 \text{ bytes}\). 3. **Logarithmic Character Encoding**: \[ \text{Bits per Character} = \lceil \log_2(\text{Unique Characters}) \rceil \] Example: \(12 \text{ characters} \rightarrow 4 \text{ bits/char}\). --- ## **Exam Tips** 1. **Flask/Jinja2**: - Understand route decorators, template inheritance, and `request` object. - Practice rendering dynamic content with Jinja2. 2. **Databases**: - Know how to define models and relationships in SQLAlchemy. - Recognize incorrect foreign key references (e.g., `library = db.Column(db.Integer(), db.ForeignKey("section.id"))` is wrong if the table is `library`). 3. **Testing**: - Remember that `pytest` runs all functions prefixed with `test_`. - Fixtures provide reusable test data. 4. **Math Problems**: - Break down bandwidth/data problems into hourly segments. - Use logarithmic calculations for encoding problems. 5. **Security**: - ABAC grants access based on attributes (e.g., department, location). - Constraint Validation API is client-side only (not secure against direct server requests). 6. **APIs**: - `GET` retrieves data, `PUT` updates, `POST` creates. - Status codes: `200` (OK), `404` (Not Found), `400` (Bad Request).
